title: Alport's Syndrome with Rapid Hearing Decline
chief_complaint: I have noticed a rapid decline in my hearing over the past 2 years. I constantly need people to repeat themselves at home and at work, and I am having a lot of trouble understanding speech in noisy situations.

problem_summary.onset: Childhood diagnosis (grade school) with stable hearing until college; rapid decline in the last 2 years.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Difficulty in noise; denies tinnitus, dizziness, or aural fullness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Requires repetition in quiet settings; significant difficulty in noise.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking evaluation; currently uses HAT for TV and theater but has never used hearing aids.

history.present_illness: Patient reports a history of hearing loss diagnosed in grade school associated with Alport's syndrome. Hearing was stable until college but has declined rapidly in the last 2 years.
history.otologic_history: No history of ear pathology, surgery, or noise exposure. Denies tinnitus or vertigo.
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with Alport's syndrome. Kidney transplant ~20 years ago which failed within 5 years. Currently on kidney dialysis. Family history: Mother has Alport's syndrome and significant hearing loss.
history.prior_management: No prior hearing tests available for comparison. No hearing aid use. Uses Assistive Listening Devices (HAT) for television and theater.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral mild sensorineural hearing loss at 250 Hz, sloping to moderate/moderately-severe in the mid-to-high frequencies (2000-6000 Hz), with some recovery at 8000 Hz. Symmetrical configuration.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores are in agreement with PTA. Word recognition scores (WRS) indicate good to excellent ability to recognize speech at suprathreshold levels (85 dB HL).

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal Type A tympanograms bilaterally, indicating normal middle ear function.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes are generally present at lower frequencies (500-1000 Hz) and absent at higher frequencies (2000-4000 Hz), consistent with the degree of cochlear hearing loss. Reflex decay was negative where measurable.

numeric_results.Left_Ipsi_500_4k: 95-100 dB HL (Image shows presence, text notes normal)
numeric_results.Contralateral_Reflexes: Generally absent or elevated in higher frequencies

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, symmetrical, mild sloping to moderately-severe sensorineural hearing loss. Speech discrimination remains good bilaterally at elevated levels. The findings are consistent with cochlear pathology secondary to Alport's syndrome. Middle ear function is normal.
counseling_points: Explain the relationship between Alport's syndrome (kidney function) and hearing loss.
Discuss the progressive nature of the hearing loss and the importance of annual monitoring.
Recommend amplification (hearing aids) to address difficulty in quiet and noise.
Discuss continued use of Hearing Assistive Technology (HAT) for specific situations like TV.
Advise on hearing protection in noisy environments to preserve remaining hearing.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is accustomed to medical procedures due to kidney history but is new to hearing intervention.
You are not in acute distress, but you are frustrated by the recent rapid decline in your ability to communicate at work.
You have never worn hearing aids before.
